case_vignette: A 27-year-old woman presents with acute abdominal pain in her right upper quadrant. The pain came on suddenly while she was eating dinner. After this pain she began feeling dizzy and came to the emergency department. In the ED, her blood pressure is 75/40 mmHg, pulse is 100/minute, and she is afebrile. On physical exam, she feels too light-headed to ambulate. She demonstrates normal bowel sounds with tenderness upon palpation in the right upper quadrant. The patient is deemed too unstable for imaging. An abdominal radiograph and CT are reviewed from a recent previous visit to the ED for mild abdominal pain, and are shown in Figures A and B, respectively.
question: Which  specific additional findings in her history supports the most likely diagnosis?
correct_ans: use of oral contraceptives (ocps) for birth control

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Gastrointestinal System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.

I don't know of any family history with similar symptoms.

Not mentioned in my case vignette, so I can't say if I've been taking medications.
Final Diagnosis: Acute Appendicitis.

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient arrives complaining of acute abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant and feeling dizzy. The patient denies having had fever, changes in diet or eating habits, recent travel or exposure to new environments, recent stressful events or changes, recent surgeries or medical procedures, and a family history of similar symptoms. The patient is unsure if they have been taking any medications.
trial_0.vignette_mcq: Symptoms that began after a fatty meal.
trial_0.vignette_frq: The patient's symptoms of sudden onset of acute abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant, dizziness, and low blood pressure and pulse suggest a possible gastrointestinal emergency. The physical exam findings of tenderness in the right upper quadrant and normal bowel sounds support this diagnosis. The radiographic findings of a dilated common bile duct (CBD) on the abdominal radiograph (Figure A) and a dilated CBD with a stone in the common hepatic duct (CHD) on the CT scan (Figure B) are consistent with cholangitis, an infection of the bile ducts. The patient's history of a recent previous visit to the ED for mild abdominal pain and the presence of a stone in the CHD on the CT scan suggest that the patient may have had a history of biliary tract disease.
trial_0.multiturn_mcq: Symptoms that began after a fatty meal.
trial_0.summarized_mcq: Symptoms that began after a fatty meal.
trial_0.summarized_frq: Additional findings in the patient's history that support the most likely diagnosis include a history of alcohol consumption, a history of taking nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and a history of gallstones.
